channel.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
channel.description:
I'm switching webhosts, and I backed up my SMF forum database.
When I import the SQL file, it says that it has done it correctly. No errors arise.
However, only a couple of tables are actually there. To be specific, around 30%.
I see tables between "attachments" to "log_banned", and from "log_boards" to "topics" there are no tables that were created. 12/38 tables. Pathetic.
I thought it was probably the max amount of lines that could be executed, so I made sure that when I exported the database that there be no maximum.
I searched the missing tables in the gigantic SQL file and sure enough, they were there. So it's not a problem with exporting.
I also tried importing without this checked: "Allow the interruption of an import in case the script detects it is close to the PHP timeout limit. (This might be good way to import large files, however it can break transactions.)"
Any ideas?

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @Agent766 Agent766
item.description:
@Agent766 wrote:

xatuser:

just go a website like x10hosting, and make a website there and u domain redirect to that cause that phpmyadmin is automaticly, updating.

What are you talking about?

OP, what you should’ve checked was if those 18 tables it did import were in order. It would’ve been easier to identify if it was timing out or just a bad dump.

Read full topic

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @xatuser xatuser
item.description:
@xatuser wrote:

just go a website like x10hosting, and make a website there and u domain redirect to that cause that phpmyadmin is automaticly, updating.

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:8, topic:433336”][quote author=whackatre link=topic=536055.msg3920295#msg3920295 date=1329634710]

Did you dump a old forum with a lot of posts into a new blank one?..
The issue is it prob overwhelmed the PHPMyAdmin (or the timeout time is too small :P)… Break up the backups into like 10 files and upload them one at a time…

Yea I’m in the process of doing that and it’s driving me crazy. Our forum has over 20K posts and there are a few tables that for some reason I can’t even import completely. I wonder how MS deals with this.
[/quote]
20k posts is not a significant number, did you happen to check the checksum of the upload to make sure its not something with your or the servers connection during transfer[/quote]

Sorry, I’m not sure what that is, but I did the transfer on the same server via localhost.

I have found a solution to my problem. This tool: Big Dump was hella awesome. Great tool, I should have searched for something like this from the very beginning.

Thanks everyone.

Read full topic

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded

Did you dump a old forum with a lot of posts into a new blank one?..
The issue is it prob overwhelmed the PHPMyAdmin (or the timeout time is too small :P)… Break up the backups into like 10 files and upload them one at a time…
[/quote]

Yea I’m in the process of doing that and it’s driving me crazy. Our forum has over 20K posts and there are a few tables that for some reason I can’t even import completely. I wonder how MS deals with this.[/quote]
20k posts is not a significant number, did you happen to check the checksum of the upload to make sure its not something with your or the servers connection during transfer

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

There’s an option in the upload dialog to split the statements up during execution, and to extend the number of statements that can execute simultaneously. You should be able to change the timeout time, too.

Read full topic

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

Not sure if it makes a difference, but try breaking up the sql file into smaller files?

Read full topic

item.title: PhpMyAdmin is being retarded
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Taharok:

What sort of errors was phpmyadmin giving after you uploaded and executed the script? Are you sure the versions are intercompatible between the old and new server?

There were no errors, it said that it was successful and did like a couple of thousand queries. I’m pretty sure the versions are compatible, if not, how do I make them compatible?

Read full topic
